bill_title: revise provisions regarding fertilizer inspection fees.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to revise provisions regarding fertilizer inspection fees. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That § 38-19-10.1 be amended to read: 38-19-10.1. In addition to the fee imposed by § 38-19-10, each licensed distributor of commercial fertilizer shall pay to the secretary of agriculture for all commercial fertilizer distributed in this state an inspection fee of twenty-five cents per ton in accordance with the provisions of § 38-19-12. However, if the distributed fertilizer is made up entirely of composted or manipulated animal manure, the fee shall only be one-fifth of the fee collected and deposited for commercial fertilizer, pursuant to this section. Notwithstanding the provisions of § 38-19-14, the fee imposed by this section shall be deposited in the precision agriculture fund created pursuant to § 13-49-38. (This section is repealed pursuant to SL 2018, ch 123, § 11 on the first day of the fiscal year following a determination by the Board of Regents that the bonds authorized pursuant to SL 2018, ch 123, § 4 are satisfied and paid in full.) Section 2. That § 38-19-49 be amended to read: 38-19-49. From each fee collected pursuant to § 38-19-10, fifty cents shall be deposited into the nutrient research and education fund created in § 38-19-48. However, if the distributed fertilizer is made up entirely of composted or manipulated animal manure, the fee shall only be one-fifth of the fee collected and deposited for commercial fertilizer, pursuant to this section. The nutrient research and education fund shall be disbursed as follows: (1) The Agriculture Experiment Station may use an amount not to exceed five percent of the revenue deposited in the fund for administrative expenses necessary to carry out the functions of §§ 38-19-48 to 38-19-51, inclusive; (2) The balance of the fund shall be used for fertilizer-related, nutrient-related, and water quality-related research and education purposes in conjunction with the Nutrient Research and Education Council; and (3) Beginning in fiscal year 2020, a minimum of ten percent of the fund shall be used to support water quality projects.

bill_versions.bill_version: House Agriculture and Natural Resources Engrossed
bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to revise provisions regarding fertilizer inspection fees. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That § 38-19-10.1 be amended to read: 38-19-10.1. In addition to the fee imposed by § 38-19-10, each licensed distributor of commercial fertilizer shall pay to the secretary of agriculture for all commercial fertilizer distributed in this state an inspection fee of twenty-five cents per ton in accordance with the provisions of § 38-19-12. However, if the distributed fertilizer is made up entirely of composted or manipulated animal manure, the fee shall only be one-fifth of the fee collected and deposited for commercial fertilizer, pursuant to this section. Notwithstanding the provisions of § 38-19-14, the fee imposed by this section shall be deposited in the precision agriculture fund created pursuant to § 13-49-38. (This section is repealed pursuant to SL 2018, ch 123, § 11 on the first day of the fiscal year following a determination by the Board of Regents that the bonds authorized pursuant to SL 2018, ch 123, § 4 are satisfied and paid in full.) Section 2. That § 38-19-49 be amended to read: 38-19-49. From each fee collected pursuant to § 38-19-10, fifty cents shall be deposited into the nutrient research and education fund created in § 38-19-48. However, if the distributed fertilizer is made up entirely of composted or manipulated animal manure, the fee shall only be one-fifth of the fee collected and deposited for commercial fertilizer, pursuant to this section. The nutrient research and education fund shall be disbursed as follows: (1) The Agriculture Experiment Station may use an amount not to exceed five percent of the revenue deposited in the fund for administrative expenses necessary to carry out the functions of §§ 38-19-48 to 38-19-51, inclusive; (2) The balance of the fund shall be used for fertilizer-related, nutrient-related, and water quality-related research and education purposes in conjunction with the Nutrient Research and Education Council; and (3) Beginning in fiscal year 2020, a minimum of ten percent of the fund shall be used to support water quality projects. Section 3. The provisions of this Act are effective on January 1, 2020.
